bestBHT.bht: We know that God hath spoken unto Moses, but as for this man, we do not know whence he is. The Pharisees, in their elevated view of God's revelation to Moses, failed to recognize the authority of Jesus. They clung to their interpretation of the law, assuming it to be infallible, and dismissed Jesus without truly understanding his origin or purpose. Their refusal to acknowledge Jesus as the one sent from God highlights their ignorance and failure to see the fulfillment of scriptures in him.

Henry Alford: God hath spoken, not spake, is important: it betokens the abiding finality of God’s revelation to Moses, in their estimation.
We stand by God’s revelation to Moses.
Why herein is,&c. This well expresses the sense of the original. Tho man takes what their words had conceded, and proceeds to argue upon it.
Albert Barnes: We know that God commanded Moses to deliver the law. In that they were correct; but they assumed their interpretation of the law to be infallible, and, hence, condemned Jesus.
The word 'fellow' implies contempt, which it cannot be proved they intended to express.
They knew not whether he was mad, whether he was instigated by the devil, or whether he spoke of himself.
Marvin Vincent: Spake. Perfect tense, hath spoken, and the authority of Moses' words therefore continues to the present.
Whence he is. Compare John 7:27; John 8:14.
John Calvin: We know not whence he is... they allege that they have no knowledge of his calling."
They refer not to his country or the place of his birth, but to the prophetical office."
They... receive him as having proceeded from God.
Philip Schaff: In holding by the law of Moses, then, they are safe and are assured that they are doing the will of God.
If they do not know the origin of ‘this man,’ he can be worthy of no regard, certainly he cannot be from God!
We know that God hath spoken unto Moses; but as for this man we know not from whence he is.
Archibald T. Robertson: We know that God hath spoken unto Moses."
But as for this man, we do not know whence he is."
These Pharisees neither knew nor cared.
John Gill: We know that God spoke to Moses,.... Out of the bush, and told him who he was, and sent him to deliver the children of Israel out of Egyptian bondage.
But as for this fellow; so they contemptuously called the Lord Jesus Christ.
We know not from whence he is; contradicting what others of them had said, John 7:27.
John Wesley: We know not whence he is — By what power and authority he does these things.

bhtAttempts.bht: We stand by God's revelation to Moses, but as for this man, we do not know whence he is. The Pharisees, in their arrogance and contempt, elevated the authority of Moses but dismissed Jesus and his miraculous works. They clung to their interpretation of the law, assuming it to be infallible, and condemned Jesus without truly understanding who he was. They questioned his origins and refused to acknowledge his divine calling. Little did they know that Jesus, the one they rejected, was the fulfillment of the very scriptures they claimed to uphold.

We stand by God's revelation to Moses, but as for this man, we do not know whence he is. The Pharisees, in their arrogance and contempt, elevated the authority of Moses but dismissed Jesus and his miraculous works. They clung to their interpretation of the law, assuming it to be infallible, and condemned Jesus without truly understanding who he was. They questioned his origins and refused to acknowledge his divine calling. Little did they know that Jesus, the one they rejected, was the fulfillment of the very scriptures they claimed to uphold. [78 words]

We know that God hath spoken unto Moses, but as for this man, we do not know whence he is. The Pharisees, in their elevated view of God's revelation to Moses, failed to recognize the authority of Jesus. They clung to their interpretation of the law, assuming it to be infallible, and dismissed Jesus without truly understanding his origin or purpose. Their refusal to acknowledge Jesus as the one sent from God highlights their ignorance and failure to see the fulfillment of scriptures in him.

We know that God hath spoken unto Moses, but as for this man, we do not know whence he is. The Pharisees, in their mistaken arrogance, held on to the authority of Moses' revelation while rejecting Jesus. They clung to their interpretation of the law, assuming it to be perfect and infallible. In their ignorance, they did not recognize Jesus' divine calling and questioned his origins. Little did they know that Jesus was the fulfillment of the very scriptures they claimed to uphold.

We stand by God's revelation to Moses, but as for this man, we do not know whence he is. The Pharisees, while upholding the authority of God's words to Moses, dismissed Jesus and his divine calling. They held onto their interpretation of the law, assuming it to be flawless, and condemned Jesus without truly understanding his origins. Their ignorance prevented them from recognizing Jesus as the fulfillment of the scriptures they purportedly followed.
